The  technical  assistance  (TA)  loan  does  not  by  itself  have  any 
environmental impact, but an environmental assessment will be an 
integral  component  of  the  subproject  preparatory  process  that  is 
financed  under  the  TA  loan.  The  Government  of  Pakistan  will 
provide  an  assurance  that  any  subproject  will  be  prepared  in 
accordance with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Environment 
Policy.  
 
The  TA  loan  provides  a  key  intervention  of  the  long-term 
partnership  between  ADB  and  Pakistan  for  the  development  of 
Karachi.  It  responds  to  the  need  for  a  long-term  and  holistic 
approach to the development of Karachi whose large-scale needs 
for  infrastructure  and  reforms  cannot  be  met  by  the  traditional 
approach  of  a  one-off  project.  The  TA  loan  supports  a  series  of 
complementary interventions whose cumulative effect will produce 
the  synergy  to  speed  up  the  development  process  of  the  mega 
city  on  a  sustainable  basis.  These 
involve 
comprehensive capacity building of city district government, town 
municipal  administrations  (TMAs),  and  other  city  agencies  in  city 
planning,  management,  and  adoption  and  implementation  of 
commercial principles in providing infrastructure and services. The 
TA loan interventions also include support for preparing bankable 
projects for the mega city infrastructure and services development 
in  an  efficient  and  integrated  manner.  Moreover,  the  TA  loan 
involves  interventions  for  sustainable  financing  of  the  mega  city 
infrastructure through introducing an innovative financing vehicle.

The  economy  and  population  of  Karachi  have  expanded 
significantly,  but  few  investments  have  been  made  in  the  city’s 
urban  infrastructure  for  over  two  decades.  Infrastructure  and 
services  that  are  inadequate  and  unreliable  are  adding  to 
business  and  household  costs,  harming  Karachi’s  urban  and 
natural  environments,  and  decreasing 
the  city’s  global 
competitiveness  compared  with  alternative  Asian  mega  cities. 
The  Government’s  recent  devolution  policy  provides  major 
benefits  to  be  realized,  but  it  has  left  many  issues  to  be 
addressed in such areas as (i) fiscal imbalance and unclear and

and  technical  capacities  to  fully  meet  their  new  responsibilities

and  long-term  capacity  building  at  the  city  and  town  levels  if 
devolution  is  to  yield  the  intended  benefits  for  more  effective 
urban  service  delivery.  There  is  also  increasing  recognition  that 
the  growing  gap  between  urban  infrastructure  demand  and 
current  supply  cannot  be  met  through  traditional  government 
sources,  including  local  government  revenues,  subsidies,  and 
transfers  from  the  higher  levels  of  government.  Alternative 
sources of financing and new ways of providing infrastructure and 
services are required.  

 
The expected impact of the TA loan is an enhanced and sustained 
contribution of Karachi to national development and a sustainable 
improvement  in  the  quality  of  life  for  the  city  residents,  including 
the  poor.  The  expected  outcomes  are  (i) improved  city  planning, 
management,  and  financing;  (ii) improved  and  expanded  urban 
infrastructure  and  services;  and  (iii)  sustainable  and  efficient 
financing  of  urban  infrastructure.  To  these  ends,  the  TA  loan  will 
provide resources for (i) building the capacities of the City District 
Government  of  Karachi  (CDGK),  TMAs,  and  utilities  in  city 
planning,  management,  and  financing,  as  well  as  in  applying 
commercial  principles  in  the  provision  of  infrastructure  and 
services;  (ii)  assisting  to  prepare  bankable  projects  that  may 
subsequently  be  funded  by  ADB  in  its  lending  assistance  to 
Karachi  over 
the  next  4  years;  and  (iii)  establishing  and 
operationalizing  an  innovative  financing  vehicle  for  mega  city 
infrastructure investments which will act as (a) an efficient conduit 
for  channeling  ADB  and  other  funds  to  the  city,  (b)  a  catalyst  for 
reforming  the  city  agencies,  and  (c)  an  agent  to  mobilize  funds 
from  nongovernment  sources  for  large-scale  capital  investment 
needs.  It  is  expected  that  the  TA  loan  will  also  enhance  the 
Government’s  ownership  of  the  investment  projects,  capacity 
building, and institutional reforms.  
 
The  total  cost  of  the  Project  is  estimated  at  $13.330  million 
equivalent,  comprising  a  foreign  exchange  component  of  $6.460 
million (48% of the total cost) and a local currency component of 
$6.870 million equivalent (52% of the total cost).

International  and/or  domestic  consulting  firms  will  be  recruited

Specialists in urban planning, water supply, sewerage, solid waste 
management,  urban  transport  and  roads,  low  income  community 
upgrading,  private  sector  participation  in  urban  infrastructure 
provision,  economics,  finance,  social  development,  resettlement,

feasibility  analyses  and,  where  necessary,  engineering  designs, 
preparation  of  bid  documents,  and  procurement  of  goods  and 
services  in  a  manner  satisfactory  to  ADB.  Specialists  in  urban 
governance,  urban/municipal  finance,  institutional  development, 
and corporate governance will also be recruited to help design and 
implement programs under the capacity building facility.

Risks and Assumptions  Major potential risks include those related to (i) possible delays in 
project  implementation  due  to  inadequate  capacities  of  CDGK, 
(ii) possible delays in government reform actions to implement the 
proposed  improvements  under  the  capacity  building  component,  
and  (iii)  a  possible  lack  of  cooperation  from  civil  society  and 
nongovernment organizations.  
 
To  mitigate  the  possible  delays  in  project  implementation,  the 
Project provides support for TA loan management whereby a core 
team of experts/advisors is to be engaged at the Project’s outset 
to  assist  the  PSU,  PWG,  and  LSU  in  reviewing  and  revising  the 
scope of components, prioritizing subprojects, finalizing the TORs, 
recruiting consultants and evaluating the consultant outputs.   
 
The  risk  of  delay  in  government  actions  to  implement  the 
proposed  reforms  for  organizational  development,  tariffs,  local 
revenues,  financial  management,  corporatization,  and  customer 
orientation  will  be  mitigated  by  close  ADB  supervision  of 
implementation.  ADB  will  be  actively  engaged  throughout  the 
progress  of  the  capacity  building  subprograms,  and  especially  in 
those  having  policy  and  sector  reform 
implications.  Each 
subprogram will identify the time-bound actions to be taken by the 
Government  at  the  early  stages  of  its  implementation  and  which 
will form the content of the policy dialogue with CDGK, GOS and 
ADB.  In  addition,  the  PSC  will  use  its  considerable  political  and 
administrative  clout  to  facilitate  timely  implementation  of  reform 
actions.  
 
Finally, the additional risk that may emerge due to possible lack of 
cooperation from civil society will be addressed through involving 
the  representatives  of  the  nongovernment  organizations  in  the 
PSC,  and  ensuring  the  participation  of  the  civil  society,  business 
community,  and  the  urban  poor  in  developing  and  implementing 
the subprojects.

Introduction  

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
In its midterm development framework, the Government of Pakistan (Government) made 
2. 
a  commitment  to  enhance  the  competitiveness  of  and  quality  of  life  in  its  large  cities.  The 
Government constituted a high-level committee led by the Planning Commission for coordinated 
development of its mega cities, starting with Karachi as a central plank in its long-term economic 
development  strategy.  In  this  context,  the  Government  requested  Asian  Development  Bank's 
(ADB) assistance to address the mega city challenges facing Pakistan. Given the immense size 
of Karachi, the magnitude of its investment requirements, and the scale of interventions for urban 
policy  reforms,  both  ADB  and  the  Government  recognized  that  the  needs  of  Karachi  cannot  be 
addressed  by  a  one-off  approach,  but,  rather  require  a  series  of  appropriately  sequenced 
interventions.  Accordingly,  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  update  (CSPU)  for  2005–2006 
included  a  TA  loan1  in  2005,  as  the  first  intervention  of  the  long-term  mega  city  assistance 
program to enable the Government to undertake preparation of priority projects, critically needed 
urban institutional and financial reforms, and comprehensive capacity building.  
 
B. 
 
Economy. Karachi, the capital of Sindh province, is the commercial hub and gateway of 
3. 
Pakistan.  It  accounts  for  95%  of  Pakistan’s  foreign  trade  and  contributes  30%  of  Pakistan’s 
industrial production. Nearly 90% of the country’s head offices of banks, financial institutions and 
multinational companies are located in Karachi. The country’s largest stock exchange is Karachi-
based.  The  city  contributes  20%  of  the  national  gross  domestic  product,  accounts  for  40%  of 
national  employment  in  large-scale  manufacturing,  and  contributes  25%  of  national  and  40%  of 
provincial revenues.  
 
Demography.  According  to  the  1998  census,  Karachi  had  a  population  of  9.2  million  in 
4. 
1998, which compares with 5.2 million in 1981. Based upon the intercensal (1981–1998) annual 
growth  rate  of  4.5%,  the  current  population  of  Karachi  is  estimated  at  12.5  million  and  the 
population is projected to reach 20.7 million in 2015. The city is made up of 18 contiguous towns.  
 
5.

Karachi  have  drawn  both  labor  and  capital  for  many  decades,  but  the  city  has  never  been  in  a 
position to maximize this potential to benefit the city. Little investment into the city’s infrastructure 
has  been  made  over  the  past  two  decades.  Neither  new  investments  nor  new  additions  to  the 
labor force have been optimally located in the city, resulting in haphazard development, a polluted 
urban environment, and, for many households, a poor quality of life.

C. 
 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

Inadequate Mega City Management: Need for Capacity Building  

1. 
 
Mega  City  Governance  in  Transition.  The  weak  city  governance  and  management 
8. 
systems lead to poor performance in planning and provision of infrastructure and services in the 
mega city. The devolution reforms of 2001 have ushered in a need for major restructuring of the 
local  government  through  transfer  of  political  and  administrative  power  to  the  elected  local 
authorities.  The  City  District  Government  of  Karachi  (CDGK)  became  the  central  player  in 
managing  the  city’s  affairs  while  the  town  municipal  administrations  (TMAs)  of  18  towns  were 
tasked with core municipal functions, including town planning and provision of infrastructure and 
services  for  water,  sanitation,  roads,  streetlights,  etc.  Although  the  devolution  has  provided  a 
good  opportunity  for  effective  service  provision,  it  has  led  to  continuing  overlaps  and 
fragmentation. Various agencies at provincial level remain responsible for service provision that is 
now the responsibility of CDGK and TMAs. The post-devolution institutional structure of CDGK is 
primarily an outcome of joining past provincial offices and their employees into CDGK, rather than 
any  major  reorganization  needed  to  undertake  the  management  of  a  mega  city  along  modern 
lines (see the organization of CDGK in Appendix 2).  
 
9. 
In the devolution process, the capacity of some technically well-endowed agencies, such 
as  the  Karachi  Development  Authority,  was  lost  without  providing  an  alternative  devolved 
structure  for  them.  The  restructuring  of  such  major  service  providers  as  Karachi  Water  and 
Sewerage  Board  (KWSB)  and  coordination  with  the  TMAs  remain  to  be  addressed.  Personnel 
administration within the devolved setup continues to be an issue. While the provincial staff were 
physically  transferred  to  CDGK,  they  remain  administratively  under  the  Government  of  Sindh 
(GOS),  limiting  the  power  of  CDGK  on  personnel  matters  and  undermining  employee  and 
management  accountability.  The  organization  is  overstaffed,  with  a  concentration  of  low-grade 
employees.  A  large  majority  of  the  staff  does  not  have  the  qualifications  and  skills  required  to 
discharge the new responsibilities and facilitate evolution of an accountable work ethic in CDGK.  
 
10. 
There  is  a  need  to  introduce  appropriate  institutional  structures,  business  practices,  and 
improved  capacities  if  the  devolution  is  to  yield  the  intended  benefits  with  regard  to  improved 
governance  and  effective  service  delivery.  This  would  require  (i)  evolution  of  new  regulatory 
relationships between GOS, CDGK, and the TMAs, with GOS and CDGK assuming greater roles 
for regulation and oversight; (ii) clarity of functional responsibilities between GOS and CDGK, as 
well  as  within  CDGK;  (iii)  organizational  development  of  CDGK  and  the  TMAs;  (iv)  introducing 
customer  orientation  and  commercialization  in  CDGK  and  utilites;  and  (v)  human  resource 

  

3

management that combines rationalization strategies, training, and personnel management for a 
productive workforce in CDGK and TMAs. These improvements form the priority subprograms of 
capacity building assistance in the Project.  

  
11. 
Lack  of  Planned  Approach  to  Development.  Inadequate  planning  systems  resulted  in 
haphazard growth of the mega city. The current planning system has not articulated into plans the 
strategic  directions  and  visions  for  the  city’s  economic  development.  The  planning  system  is 
neither  linked  to  prioritized  action  plans  nor  to  financial  strategies  needed  to  realize  them.  The 
recent  master  plan,  prepared  for  the  period  up  to  2000,  was  not  adopted  due  to  lack  of 
institutional clarity for approving and implementing plans. Master planning has been constrained 
by (i) a lack of strategic guidance, (ii) institutional uncertainty, (iii) land management issues of the 
mega  city,  and  (iv)  ineffective  building  control  and  enforcement.  The  situation  has  been 
aggravated  by  the  fact  that  nearly  90%  of  city  land  is  under  the  ownership  of  various  public 
institutions, each of which has authority over land use and planning with regard to its own land.  
 
Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation  (JBIC)  has  recently  supported  a  study4  for  the 
12. 
“revitalization of Karachi.” A vision for Karachi was established as a “cosmopolitan gateway city” 
of international business and tourism. This vision would be achieved through (i) social upgrading, 
involving  tourism  and  business  infrastructure  and  amenities,  welfare  services,  skills  upgrading, 
and  citizen  mobilization;  and  (ii)  urban  and  industrial  development  through  infrastructure 
development,  possible  renovation  of  Karachi’s  circular  railway,  and  improving  the  urban 
environment.  There  remains  a  need,  however,  to  translate  this  vision  into  concrete  plans  and 
programs. CDGK recently embarked on preparing an updated mega city master plan. Building on 
the  work  done  by  JBIC,  the  proposed  TA  loan  will  support  CDGK  in  its  endeavor  for  mega  city 
planning.  The  planning  assistance  is  also  aimed  to  be  instrumental  in  developing  and 
institutionalizing a planning system that (i) integrates economic, social, environmental and spatial 
planning;  (ii)  is  linked  to  financing  strategies  for  implementing  the  plans;  (iii)  is  based  on  clear 
institutional  roles  to  approve  and  implement  the  plans;  and  (iv)  is  supplemented  by  effective 
development and building control systems.

Inadequate Infrastructure and Services and Need for Upgrading/Expansion  

 
A major outcome of the weak governance and management of the mega city has been the 
18. 
inadequate  urban  infrastructure  and  services,  including  water  supply,  sewerage,  drainage,  solid 
waste management, urban transport and roads, and basic services for the city’s poor.  
 
19.  Water. While an estimated 82% of households have a water supply connection, water is 
available in the network only for a few hours every second day. With the exception of one or two 
towns, many households rely on tankers to supply potable water. System losses (technical and 
administrative)  are  high  and  occur  through  leakages,  illegal  connections,  and  the  lack  of 
metering. Water quality is poor, and over 75% of water samples taken from the system are below 
World Health Organization standards. This is due to (i) the lack of adequate treatment and poor 
functioning  of  treatment  plants,  and  (ii)  intermittent  flow  and  variable  pressures  in  the  system. 
Problems are aggravated by a lack of long-term system planning for water supply and sewerage 
and insufficient cost-recovery measures that result in poor operation and maintenance.

20. 
Sewerage and Drainage. Although an estimated 89% of households have a flush toilet, 
connected to either a sewer or septic tank, the sewerage network suffers from poor connectivity 
and a large number of undersized and broken sections. The sewerage treatment plants function 
at below their capacity due to inadequate maintenance and frequent blockages caused by solid 
waste  entering  the  plants.  Much  of  the  untreated  industrial  and  domestic  wastewater  is 
discharged into the stormwater drainage system and rivers and thence to Karachi Harbor and the 
Arabian Sea. A large part of the stormwater drainage functions as part of the wastewater disposal 
system. Most of the drainage lines are heavily encroached and used for disposing of solid waste. 
There is need (i) in the short term for programs to establish drainage rights of way and systems of 
routine maintenance, (ii) in the medium term for a drainage master plan, and (iii) for progressively 
achieving separation between wastewater and stormwater systems.      
 
21. 
Solid Waste Management. An estimated 7,250 tons of solid waste is generated daily in 
the city. Only about 60% of this is collected, and no more than 25% of that amount makes it to 
one  of  the  two  designated  city  “landfill”  sites—actually  open  dumping  sites.  The  remainder  is 
either recovered for recycling or is disposed of by burning or by illegal dumping into open spaces. 
The piles of uncollected waste are a nuisance and attract vermin that can carry disease. Informal 
solid  waste  recycling  is  significant.  The  poor  performance  in  solid  waste  management  is 
exacerbated by (i) lack of a practical waste management plan involving all stakeholders (e.g., the 
formal and informal private sectors), (ii) lack of mechanisms and sound feasibility studies required 
for outsourcing to the private sector, and (iii) inadequate capacities for tracking and monitoring of 
the solid waste systems. 
 
22. 
Urban Transport. The city population relies almost entirely on the road network for urban 
transportation. There is currently no mass transit system per se, although many commute using 
the  network  of  bus  routes.  Rapid  growth  rate  of  private  vehicles  (9%  per  annum)  leads  to 
overcrowding,  air  pollution,  and  accidents.  While  there  has  been  a  significant  program  of  road 
building, no major investment in public transport systems has taken place. Attempts to revive the 
Karachi circular railway and a light rail mass transit system have failed to attract public or private 
investment.  The  quality  of  major  thoroughfares  is  generally  good,  but  the  distributor  network 
varies dramatically. The current focus on primary networks in the absence of a distributor network 
is resulting in reduced benefits from investments in primary networks. The sector operations have 
been adversely affected by (i) lack of clarity on institutional roles and overlapping responsibilities 
between  several  departments  of  CDGK5  and  (ii)  lack  of  a  transport  master  plan  to  guide  future 
development of roads and public transport and a strategy for financing the city’s transport system.

Summary of the Rationale 

 
 
35. 
The  economy  and  population  of  Karachi  have  expanded  significantly,  but  provision  of 
infrastructure and services has not kept pace with this rapid growth in the absence of funds and 
adequate mega city governance and management systems. Infrastructure and services that are 
insufficient  and  unreliable  are  adding  to  business  and  household  costs,  hurting  Karachi’s  urban 
and  natural  environments,  and  decreasing  the  city’s  global  competitiveness  compared  with 
alternative Asian mega cities.  
 
36. 
Devolution has provided opportunities for effective service delivery but left many issues to 
be addressed in areas such as (i) fiscal imbalance, limited revenues, and unclear and incomplete 
allocation  of  responsibilities  between  levels  of  government;  and  (ii)  the  inadequacy  of  the  city’s 
and  towns’  financial  and  technical  capacities  to  fully  meet  their  new  responsibilities  within  the 
devolved framework. There is need for substantial and long-term capacity building at the city level 
if  the  devolution  is  to  yield  the  intended  benefits  for  improved  governance  and  more  effective 
urban service delivery. There is also increasing recognition that the growing gap between urban 
infrastructure demand and current supply cannot be met through traditional government sources, 
including  local  government  revenues,  subsidies,  and  transfers  from  the  higher  levels  of 
government.  Alternative  sources  of  financing  and  new  ways  of  providing  infrastructure  and 
services  are  required.  Provision  of  urban  infrastructure  services  need  to  be  placed  on  a  fully 
commercial and self-sustaining basis. Meanwhile, necessary regulatory and institutional reforms 
should be effected.   
 
37. 
  Previous  external  assistance  in  Karachi  has  been  piecemeal  and  has  not  been  based 
upon an integrated approach to improve urban infrastructure and services on a sustainable basis. 
The proposed TA loan is intended to address the mega city development needs with a long-term 
and  holistic  approach  through  (i)  building  capacities  at  the  local  level  for  effective  city  planning 
and  management,  (ii)  adopting  and  implementing  commercial  principles  in  the  provision  of 
infrastructure  and  services,  (iii)  supporting  the  preparation  of  bankable  projects  for  mega  city 
development  that  may  subsequently  be  funded  by  ADB  in  its  loans  to  Karachi  initially  over  the 
next  4  years,  and  (iv)  promoting  reforms  for  sustainable  financing.  The  TA  loan  represents  the 
first intervention of a long-term assistance from ADB, and it will establish the required foundation 
for effectively utilizing and sustaining future ADB investments in the mega city.

consultant counterparts will include but not be limited to (i) review, revise, and adjust as 
necessary the proposed scope of the capacity building program; (ii) provide an updated 
capacity building program and describe the prioritization and overall programming of the

subprogram; (iv) assist in preparing RFPs and engaging consultants for individual 
subprograms; (v) assist in reviewing and evaluating the reports and proposals of 
subproject consultants; and (vi) identify the actions required to be taken by the 
Government to implement the city governance reform proposals (organizational 
development reforms, etc.) under the capacity building program and liaise with the PSU 
and LSU to ensure that the required actions are taken.  
 
The tasks of the advisor on infrastructure planning and engineering and his/her local 
consultant counterparts will include but not be limited to (i) review, revise and adjust the 
list of proposed projects included under the project preparation facility;  (ii) provide 
where necessary an updated and well justified pipeline of projects; (iii) undertake an 
overall programming of the feasibility studies for infrastructure investments; (iv) review 
the existing TORs and make adjustments to them as necessary, then finalize those 
TORs selected for investment; (v) where necessary, prepare new project profiles and 
TORs in accordance with the reprioritization of the subprojects; (vi) coordinate with the 
capacity building advisor for necessary synchronization of individual capacity building 
programs and investment project preparation; (vii) assist in engaging consultants for 
subprojects; and (viii) assist in reviewing and evaluating the subproject consultant 
outputs/reports.  
 
The tasks of the advisor on urban finance will include but not be limited to (i) reviewing, 
updating, and programming of capacity building activities and programs on  financial 
management, revenue mobilization, and commercialization of the Karachi  Water and 
Sewerage Board and CDGK; (ii) adjusting where necessary the capacity building 
activities related to the above; (iii) identifying reform actions that need to be undertaken 
by the province or CDGK to implement the financial management, revenue mobilization 
and commercialization improvements and prepare and finalize a reform agenda to 
implement reforms; (iv) liaise with the PSU and LSU to implement the reforms and 
prepare an agenda for the project steering committee to bring the reform issues to the 
attention of high-level decision makers. In addition, the advisor and his/her counterparts 
will coordinate with specialized financing vehicle consultants and provide assistance to 
the PSU in executing and implementing the financing vehicle component. Moreover, the 
advisor and his/her local counterparts will assist the PSU and LSU in engaging 
financing vehicle and capacity building consultants and in reviewing their outputs.

financial and economic viability of investment projects.
